title: Nautical Terms
description: How well do you know sailing and nautical vocabulary?

questions.question: What does the nautical term 'port' refer to?
options: The left side of the ship when facing forward
The right side of the ship when facing forward
questions.explanation: 'Port' refers to the left side of a ship when you are facing the bow (front). It replaced the older term 'larboard' to avoid confusion with 'starboard.' Port is associated with the color red in navigation lights.

questions.question: What is the 'bow' of a ship?
questions.explanation: The bow is the forward-most part of a ship's hull. It is designed to reduce the resistance of the hull cutting through water and to improve the vessel's speed and efficiency.

questions.question: What does 'starboard' mean?
options: The right side of the ship when facing forward
The left side of the ship
questions.explanation: 'Starboard' refers to the right side of a ship when facing the bow. The term comes from the Old English 'steorbord,' meaning 'steering side,' as early ships were steered with a paddle on the right side. It is associated with the color green in navigation lights.

questions.question: What is the 'stern' of a ship?
options: The back or rear of the ship
questions.explanation: The stern is the rear or back end of a ship. It is the opposite of the bow. The word comes from the Old Norse 'stjorn,' meaning 'steering,' as early rudders were mounted at the stern.

questions.question: What is an 'anchor' used for on a ship?
options: To hold the ship in place in the water
questions.explanation: An anchor is a heavy device, typically made of metal, that is lowered to the sea floor to hold a ship in a fixed position. Anchors grip the bottom through their weight and design, preventing the vessel from drifting.

questions.question: What does 'knot' mean as a unit of speed at sea?
questions.explanation: A knot is a unit of speed equal to one nautical mile per hour (approximately 1.15 statute miles per hour or 1.852 kilometers per hour). The term comes from the practice of measuring speed by counting knots in a rope trailed behind the ship over a set time.

questions.question: What is the 'hull' of a ship?
options: The main body or shell of the vessel
questions.explanation: The hull is the main structural body of a ship, the watertight shell that sits in the water. It provides buoyancy and supports the entire vessel. Hull design affects a ship's speed, stability, and cargo capacity.

questions.question: What does 'galley' refer to on a ship?
questions.explanation: The galley is the kitchen or cooking area on a ship. The term has been used since the days of ancient oar-powered warships (also called galleys). Ship galleys are designed to be compact and secure cooking equipment against the motion of the sea.

questions.question: What does 'draft' (or 'draught') mean in nautical terms?
options: The depth of water a ship needs to float
A gust of wind at sea
The air flow through the ship's cabins
A preliminary map of a voyage
questions.explanation: A ship's draft is the vertical distance between the waterline and the bottom of the hull (the keel). It indicates the minimum depth of water a ship can safely navigate. A ship with a deep draft needs deeper water to avoid running aground.

questions.question: What is the 'helm' of a ship?
options: The lookout platform at the top of the mast
The steering apparatus, including the wheel or tiller
The lowest deck of the ship
questions.explanation: The helm is the steering mechanism of a ship, which can be a wheel, tiller, or other device used to control the rudder and direct the vessel's course. The person at the helm is called the helmsman.

questions.question: What does 'fathom' mean as a nautical measurement?
options: A unit of speed at sea
A unit of distance equal to one mile
A unit of depth equal to six feet
questions.explanation: A fathom is a unit of length used to measure the depth of water, equal to six feet (1.83 meters). The word comes from the Old English 'faethm,' meaning 'outstretched arms,' as the measurement was originally based on the span of a person's arms.

questions.question: What does 'leeward' mean?
options: Away from the wind; the sheltered side
questions.explanation: 'Leeward' refers to the direction away from the wind, or the sheltered side of something (such as a ship or island). It is the opposite of 'windward,' which faces the wind. The leeward side offers protection from the wind and waves.

questions.question: What does 'keelhaul' historically mean?
options: To load cargo into the hull
To repair the keel of a ship
To drag a person under the ship as punishment
questions.explanation: Keelhauling was a severe form of punishment used at sea, in which a person was tied to a rope and dragged under the keel of the ship from one side to the other. The barnacles on the hull would cause terrible injuries. It was practiced by various navies from the 15th to 19th centuries.

questions.question: What is a 'bulkhead' on a ship?
options: A decorative figurehead on the bow
An upright wall or partition within the hull
questions.explanation: A bulkhead is a vertical wall or partition inside a ship that divides the hull into separate compartments. Bulkheads strengthen the ship's structure and, importantly, can contain floodingâ€”if one compartment is breached, the bulkheads prevent water from filling the entire vessel.

questions.question: What does 'to batten down the hatches' mean?
options: To secure and prepare for difficult conditions
To drop anchor in a harbor
To open the ship's windows for ventilation
questions.explanation: 'To batten down the hatches' means to prepare for trouble or difficulty by securing everything. On a ship, hatches are openings in the deck, and battens are strips of wood used to fasten tarpaulins over them to keep water out during storms.
